awd_titl_txt: Magmatic Volatiles, Unraveling the Reservoirs and Processes of the Volcanism in the Antarctic Peninsula
awd_abstract_narration:
The Earth's mantle influences the movement of tectonic plates and volcanism on the surface.  One way to understand the composition and nature of the Earth's mantle is by studying the chemistry of basalts, which originate by volcanic eruptions of partially melting mantle rocks.  This study will establish the budget and distribution of volatile elements (hydrogen, carbon, fluorine, chlorine, sulfur) in volcanic basalts to better understand the composition of the Earth's interior.  Volatiles influence mantle melting, magma crystallization, magma migration and volcanic eruptions.  Their abundances and spatial distribution provide important constraints on models of mantle flow and temperature. Moreover, volatiles are key constituents of the Earth's atmosphere and oceans.  Establishing the cycles of volatiles between the Earth's interior and surface is of fundamental importance to understand the long-term evolution of our planet.  This project supports a graduate student and research scientist at Brown University. It promotes the collaboration with geochemists from eleven institutions representing six different countries: USA, Germany, United Kingdom, Argentina, South Korea and Japan, and utilizes several NSF-funded USA analytical facilities.  Communication of results will occur through: 1) peer-reviewed journals, presentations at conferences and invited university lectures, 2) hands-on science learning activities for local elementary and high school classes, and 3) outreach to the general audience through public lectures.

Over the last 60 years of funded research, the Antarctic Peninsula and nearby ocean ridges have been extensively investigated providing information on the origin of the magmatism, and the composition, structure, temperature and evolution of the lithospheric and asthenospheric mantle. Diverse hypotheses have been proposed for the origin of the magmatism in the Antarctic Peninsula, from flux melting of the mantle wedge during devolatilization of the subducted Phoenix plate, to adiabatic decompression melting of a carbonated and hydrous asthenosphere, to melting of a volatile-rich metasomatized subcontinental lithospheric mantle. All proposed hypotheses invoke the role of volatiles. Surprisingly, data on the volatile contents of basalts and mantle from this region are non-existent. This is a significant omission from the geochemical data set, given the important role volatile elements play in the generation and composition of magmas and their sources. The focus of our research is to examine the regional variations in volatile contents (C, H, F, S, Cl) in geochemically well-characterized Pliocene-recent basalts from the Antarctic Peninsula and Phoenix ridge. Our goal is to establish the budget and distribution of volatiles in the mantle to understand 1) the processes responsible for the generation of chemically diverse basalts in close spatial and temporal proximity and 2) the nature (lithology, composition and temperature) of the heterogeneous mantle source beneath the Antarctic Peninsula and Phoenix ridge.

por.por_cntn:
We rely on the chemical studies of erupted lavas to understand the sources and processes controlling the geodynamics of the Earth’s upper mantle. The basalts chemical compositions  allow us to infer  the architecture of the Earth's mantle, how heterogeneous it is, the spatial scale and distribution of those heterogeneities, the probable age and generation processes that gave origin to those heterogeneities.

This project allowed us to examine the Earth's mantle regional variation along a transect from the Phoenix ridge, to the South Shetlands volcanic islands, to the Bransfield strait and the Prince Gutav Channel using  basalts erupted over the last 6 million years. Moreover we were able to report for the first time the volatiles element contents (H, C, F, S, Cl) of the lavas and infer the different source compositions beneath this region.

We determine four different mantle compositions with significant interaction among them. Two mantle components are found in the Phoenix and West Scotia Ridges is  typical to the Pacific basin. There is no evidence of south Atlantic mantle reservoir anywhere within the studied area as previously proposed. The Pacific mantle was brought into the region through the  opening of the Drake passage and the eastward expansion of the Scotia Plate. A third mantle component seems to be endemic to the Antarctic peninsula and sourrunding ridges, we are evaluating the origin of this third mantle component, which at this moment remains uncertain. Finally we determine a fourth mantle component that is the modification of the previous three components due to the underthrusting of the Phoenix plate under the Antarctic Peninsula,  trasnfering surface sediments and fluids into the Earth interior.

Simple modeling allow us to constrain the flux of sediments and fluids into the mantle.  Beneath the Bransfield strait and Prince Gustav channel  the flux of surface sediments and fluids into the mantle range from 3% to 0% by mass, with a fluid to sediment mass ratio of ~1. In contrast, the mantle beneath the South Shetland Volcanic Islands has been modified by the addition of ~3%  sediments and fluids  with a fluid/sediment ratios that ranges from ~0.18 to 4. The range in fluid/sediment ratios in the South Shetland lavas defines a spatio-temporal variation. South Shetland lavas in the southwest with eruption ages of 145 to 90 million years point to mantle that has been modified by a larger fraction of  sediments with fluid/sediment ratios of 0.18 to 1, whereas South Shetland lavas in the northeast with eruption ages from 90 million years to recent indicate a mantle  modified by a large fraction of fluids  with fluid/sediment ratios of 1 to 4. 

The observed  spatial compositional variation of the lavas along the sample transect points to four distinct mantle components that have been flowing in both direction along the edges of the underthrusted Phoenix plate.

Another important result from this study is that the new volatile data is currently been used to estimate more precisely the thermal structure of the mantle from seismological data, which  hinges critically on incorporating information  on the volatile contents to the seismic tomography.

This project  provided an excellent opportunity to a graduate student Danny Anderson  to work on his Ph.D. thesis and to   collaborate with  a significant group of national and international scientists from five different countries. It also allowed him to present the results in international conference. Furthermore this project supported  four different analytical facilities in two US institutions (Brown University and Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution).
